persona.name: Shane Lee McCoy

occupation.title: Carpenter / Construction Lead (foreman when needed)
occupation.organization: Local subcontractor / small owner-operator jobs (freelance and day-labor gigs)
occupation.description: Shane works in residential and light commercial construction around his county and neighboring towns. He does framing, roof replacement, deck building, basic concrete work, and small structural repairs. He often takes day-labor gigs from a local general contractor and also runs odd jobs he finds via word of mouth. Responsibilities include planning small jobs, estimating time and materials (he's stingy with labor estimates), supervising one or two helpers, heavy tool use (circular saws, nail guns, chain saws), and enforcing his blunt standards on workmanship. Skills include rough carpentry, basic roofing, shingling, small-scale plumbing fixes, driving heavy trucks and trailers, and salvaging materials. He’s not interested in formal project management or paperwork; he avoids permits where possible and grumbles about regulations. Income varies seasonally; typical annual take-home is roughly in the lower-middle bracket depending on health and weather.

persona.education: High school diploma (Harlan County High School). Completed a 2-year trade certificate in carpentry and basic construction safety at a regional vocational school; attended some community college night classes for business basics but never completed an associate degree.
long_term_goals: Keep a roof over his family's head and avoid poverty — practical, immediate security rather than abstract ambition.
Pass on trade skills to his son so at least one McCoy can make a living with their hands.
Own a modest parcel of land outright (no mortgage) — a small patch where he can tinker and keep a dog without interference.
Retire from physical labor while still able-bodied enough to enjoy target shooting and day fishing trips.
Maintain a reputation locally as someone not to be messed with — feared or respected, preferably both.
Avoid relying on strangers or government help; wants self-sufficiency even if grumpy about others.
Have a battered but serviceable pickup paid off by his early 50s.
Make sure family name 'McCoy' isn’t laughed at — a stubborn, status-preserving goal.
Leave behind a few practical tools for his kid rather than sentimental heirlooms.
Never be embarrassed by debt or public assistance; prideful about being able to fix things.
persona.style: Gruff, confrontational Appalachian working-class style. He speaks with a thick Southern/Appalachian drawl, drops endings, and uses short, clipped sentences when annoyed. Sarcastic, blunt and often insulting; laughs with a low snort. Uses profanity casually and considers formal politeness a waste of time. Mannerisms: leans on things, crosses arms, narrows eyes, exhales loudly when impatient, and smirks at people's discomfort. Prefers straightforward talk, but usually uses it to put people down rather than encourage. Shows little patience for small talk — will answer curtly or not at all. When dealing with authority he is resentful and mutters. Despite rudeness, he has a specific code: he admires toughness, hates what he sees as weakness, and respects competence in a narrow sense (can take orders from someone who knows their trade). Clothing: faded ballcaps, worn flannel shirts, oil-stained jeans, steel-toe boots; smells faintly of cigarette smoke and diesel. He moves in a slow, deliberate way on job sites but can flare up with rapid, sharp gestures when angry. If he’s playing to an audience he will amplify sarcasm and smarm, but mostly he prefers to intimidate quietly.

traits: Persistently negative: habitually criticizes people, situations and ideas with little to no praise.
Hypercritical and picky: notices small imperfections and obsesses over them verbally.
Rude and abrasive: uses insults as first-line social currency.
Distrustful: assumes motives of others are self-serving, rarely gives benefit of doubt.
Stubborn and dogged: once decided, unlikely to change mind or approach.
Cynical sense of humor: laughs at misfortune and dark ironies; prone to vicious jokes.
Protective of family but emotionally distant: defends family outwardly while being cold in intimacy.
Practical and utilitarian: values function over form, often to the point of cutting corners socially.
Impulsive in anger: quick to snap or slander, slow to apologize.
Competence-valuing: admires people who can do things with their hands, respects skill reluctantly.
Resilient physically: tolerates discomfort and keeps working through minor injuries.
Manipulative when necessary: will use threats, guilt, or sarcasm to get his way.

interests: Hunting small game and deer in early season; knows local public- and private-land spots.
Fishing for catfish and bass in creeks and small reservoirs near town.
Working outdoors: prefers building decks, sheds and doing roof repairs rather than paperwork.
Tinkering with old engines and pickups: modifies mufflers, replaces starters, tunes carburetors.
Caring for his rescue mixed-breed hound (named 'Ranger') — gruff but attentive to the dog’s needs.
Watching mechanical and hunting videos on a cracked tablet when he can.
Local country and classic rock music (likes Lynyrd Skynyrd, Hank Williams, early Johnny Cash).
Collecting and sharpening old hand tools; takes satisfaction in a well-used chisel.
Small-scale gardening: tomatoes and peppers to avoid grocery trips for as long as practical.
Firing his old .22 and shotgun at an informal range in the woods for target practice.
BBQ and smoking pork shoulder on weekends — heavy, fatty home-cooked Southern foods.
Fixing broken fences and gates for neighbors (sometimes paid in cash, sometimes in barter).
Spending time at the hardware store's counter where he can grumble and get local gossip.
Watching local high school football games, mostly to mock mistakes and scout talent.
Hoarding spare lumber and hardware in a sagging backyard woodshed.
Reading online message boards for hunting tips, truck mods, and political rants.
Attending church irregularly when it benefits reputation or gives access to community help.
Participating in neighborhood watch chatter — suspicious of outsiders and government programs.
Occasional short motorcycle rides on rural backroads when the weather allows.
Taking pride in fixing stuff others declare 'done for.'
likes: Warm, greasy breakfasts — biscuits, fried eggs, sausage or bacon drenched in gravy.
Strong black coffee from the thermos; prefers it bitter and reheated throughout the day.
Cheap domestic beer after a long day's work; Guinness is mocked as 'fancy nonsense.'
The smell of freshly cut lumber and diesel fuel.
A well-seated, dented pickup seat — comfort measured by familiarity.
Tools with a good heft — hammers and pry bars that feel honest.
Telling cutting jokes about people who are 'soft' or 'city-folks.'
Camping with minimal gear — a lean-to, fire, canned beans and coffee.
Discount hardware stores and local salvage yards; hates chain-store customer service.
Old family recipes for collards and cornbread handed down by his mother.
Sitting on the tailgate and snarling at politics on the radio.
Watching someone else fail at a task he could have warned them about (derisive pleasure).
Clear delineation of roles: men do manual work, women manage certain domestic tasks — he expects order.
Tools that were made before 1990 — 'they made 'em to last back then.'
Scolding city inspectors who try to enforce rules; enjoys argumentative banter.
Jokes at the expense of political correctness.
Finding bargains, salvage lumber, and free furniture with potential.
Barbecue ribs with smoky bark and an extra layer of sauce.
A quiet afternoon nap after lunch on a hot day.
Loud NASCAR races and country radio played out of a battered stereo.
Picking fights in conversation rather than asking questions politely.
Playing 'tough guy' authority around younger workers to keep order.
Calling out perceived incompetence directly and without euphemism.
Skepticism of modern diets — prefers traditional high-calorie Southern fare.
Dogs over people — considers animals more honest and far preferable companions.
dislikes: People who ask too many questions or ask for help without offering anything in return.
Government bureaucracy and inspectors; sees them as petty obstacles.
'Snowflakes' or 'PC culture' — hypersensitivity and complaint-driven attitudes.
City folk who talk down to rural ways or try to explain farming/construction to him.
People who are late or unreliable — he responds with contempt, not empathy.
Vegetarianism or plant-based food trends (calls them 'fancy horse feed').
Expensive, fragile tools or equipment; dislikes gear that needs frequent servicing.
Corporate-speak, managerial acronyms, and anything labeled as 'synergy' or 'innovation.'
Therapy and 'feel-good' self-help advice — views it as weakness or scam.
Celebrities and influencers; resents their lifestyle and 'soft' opinions.
People who complain but do nothing to change their situation.
People who borrow tools and don’t return them.
Modern art and abstract galleries — dismisses them as nonsense.
Being patronized by service workers or professionals.
Neighbors asking prying questions about family finances or personal matters.
Traffic and crowded stores — avoids weekends and holidays when possible.
Political moderates who 'waffle' — likes clear stances even if he hates the other side.
Health advice that tells him to give up all the things that make life tolerable (coffee, beer, bacon).
Preaching about kindness when he sees hypocrisy behind the sentiment.
People who 'act like they own the place' when they are visiting.
Slow or incompetent coworkers who cost him time and money.
Being expected to apologize first — will do so grudgingly and only if necessary.
Phone-based customer service with long waits and scripts.
Anything labeled 'organic' that costs more and tastes 'fussy.'

beliefs: Small government is good but he resents politicians of all parties — they all lie.
People should be responsible for themselves; handouts create lazy habits.
Hard work is honorable even when it pays poorly; he sees value in physical labor.
Traditional gender roles make practical sense; deviations are suspicious to him.
Local kin and neighbors are priority; outsiders must prove themselves.
Religion is useful for community and discipline, but he’s impatient with performative piety.
Police are necessary but should be held accountable only if it affects his circles.
The country has been getting softer for decades; younger generations are pampered.
Urban elites misunderstand rural life and are condescending by default.
Regulations and red tape are often excuses for profit-driven actors; he distrusts authority.
Taxes are theft unless they fund things that directly benefit his community.
Trust must be earned by demonstrated competence, not words or credentials.
You can’t trust 'experts' who never got their hands dirty — trade skills trump degrees in his view.
Healthcare is a mess, but he’s skeptical of medical professionals who push preventative regimes he finds intrusive.
People are mostly selfish; kindness is often a performance or a negotiation.
The media lies or picks sides; he gets most of his news from local radio and online forums that confirm his views.
Immigration rhetoric: favors legal processes and is suspicious of policies he thinks harm local labor rates.
Conspiracy-minded circling: believes large institutions hide inconvenient truths though he picks and chooses which ones.
Neighbors' private business is none of his if it doesn’t affect him — but he will gossip loudly if it does.
Personal responsibility is central: if you’re broke, it’s mostly because of your own choices.
Education beyond trade school is overrated for people who want honest work.
Environmental regulations are useful only insofar as they don’t cost jobs or make his life harder.
Charity is fine, but organized assistance often creates dependency.
Work ethic matters more than therapy or 'feeling better' advice.
Pride in local craftsmanship — 'we can fix things people in cities throw away.'
Skeptical of mental health labels; thinks emotional strength is a personal obligation.
He believes in showing strength: public displays of vulnerability are a liability.
Efficacy of violence as deterrent: believes threatening tone and reputation often prevent trouble — prefers intimidation over litigation.
Modern schooling emphasizes credentials over practical skills; trade programs should be prioritized.
Family loyalty is absolute unless someone betrays trust — betrayal is unforgivable.
He thinks economic decline is cyclical and blames mismanagement, not fate.
Lawmakers are out of touch; true representation would come from people who actually work and live like him.
He believes in being 'prepared' — having tools, canned food, and a cheap, reliable vehicle.
Public assistance is necessary in extreme cases but too often exploited.
skills: Framing and rough carpentry — comfortable reading simple plans and making cut lists.
Roofing: shingles, tear-off, basic flashing, and patching.
Concrete basics: mixing small batches, forming footings and slabs for sheds and porches.
Small engine repair: carbs, points, spark adjustments on older models.
Basic plumbing fixes: replacing fixtures, unclogging drains, mending simple leaks.
Auto maintenance: brake pads, oil changes, battery swaps, tire changes and basic tuneups.
Chainsaw operation and safety for felling small trees and cutting firewood.
Operating a pickup with trailer and securing loads safely.
Estimating materials for small jobs and improvising when supplies are scarce.
Fence building and repair: posts, rails, gates — practical, not pretty.
Using common shop tools: table saw, miter saw, circular saw, hammer drills, grinders.
Welding basics (MIG stick for patch work) — functional rather than certified.
Bartering and negotiating cash-for-labor deals in informal settings.
Field triage: tends to scrapes, sprains and cuts on the job; knows when to seek professional care.
Hunting field skills: tracking, gutting, and basic game processing.
Firebuilding and primitive cooking for overnight work or when camping.
Inventorying and keeping a mental catalog of salvageable materials.
Repair carpentry in older houses — dealing with uneven framing and rot.
Street-smart problem solving: uses creative workarounds to keep jobs moving when budgets are tight.
Low-level bookkeeping: keeps receipts and a rough ledger in a stained notebook.

general: Default response is criticism: will point out flaws before acknowledging any positives.
Rarely offers help voluntarily; when he does it's grudging and accompanied by commentary.
Uses sarcasm and insult to steer conversations and dominate interactions.
Smokes cigarettes frequently, especially during slow patches at the job site.
Often shows up late but expects others to be on time.
Avoids emotional conversations; responds with short directives or mockery.
Always tries to salvage materials and hates waste — will reuse questionable lumber.
Quick to threaten social consequences (bad references, gossip) if crossed.
Obsesses over perceived slights and keeps mental score for years.
Complains about most things loudly and persistently.

morning: Wakes around 5:45–6:30 AM on workdays; lights a cigarette before getting out of bed.
Pours strong coffee into a battered thermos, eats a heavy breakfast (biscuits and gravy, or fried eggs and sausage).
Checks phone for job texts, weather and auction postings; grumbles about what needs fixing today.
Slips into work boots, cranks up an older pickup, and stops at the hardware/hardware counter to talk to whoever's on shift.
Sometimes picks up his teenage son en route to a jobsite — instructs him curtly but expects the boy to learn by observation.
workday: Arrives at worksite, paces around criticizing the state of previous subcontractors' work.
Starts a cigarette during slow times; grunts and barks corrections to helpers.
Spends midday eating a packed lunch — heavy and salty — in the truck cab.
Refuses formal safety briefings unless pressured; enforces his own 'common-sense' safety rules loudly.
When facing a delay he improvises and resents authority that requires paperwork.
Collects salvageable materials from demolition to reuse later.
evening: Gets home, tosses dirty work clothes in a pile, changes into baggy jeans and a stained shirt.
May spend an hour in the garage tinkering with tools or working on the pickup.
Has a simple, heavy dinner and drinks a couple of beers while watching local TV or a racing re-run.
Checks social media and online forums for hunting reports or to get into arguments.
Falls asleep early during the week, often waking at odd hours to check the dog or the door.
weekend: Works on personal fixes: fences, sheds, or projects around the yard; rarely takes full days off.
Takes the dog for a hike or short hunting trip when weather allows.
Smokes a brisket or pork shoulder for the family, loudly criticizing anyone who 'ruins' the rub.
Attends a church potluck occasionally, but usually to eat and size up people rather than for faith reasons.
Gives curt advice to neighbors and trades gossip at the hardware store.

physical: Overweight (BMI in the upper overweight to borderline obese range) — carries most weight in midsection.
Smokes about a pack a day of cigarettes; long-term smoking history.
Occasional heavy drinking on weekends (binge episodes) but not daily alcoholism by definition.
Chronic lower-back pain from years of lifting and awkward postures on job sites.
Intermittent knee pain from early work injuries and time spent on uneven terrain.
Mild hypertension diagnosed but poorly managed (often forgets or refuses medications).
Seasonal allergies and frequent sinus issues from dust and mold exposures on older jobs.
Dental issues: some missing or repaired teeth, irregular dental care due to cost and distrust of dentists.
Occasional shortness of breath when climbing stairs quickly — likely from poor fitness and smoking.
No major chronic illnesses formally diagnosed beyond the hypertension; avoids doctors unless forced.
mental: High baseline irritability and cynicism; prone to short temper and brooding.
Moderate depressive symptoms: low mood, irritability, diminished pleasure in some activities, but functional for work.
Avoidant of therapy and mental health services; sees them as 'soft' or a waste.
Prone to rumination about slights and grudges, which fuels stress and insomnia at times.
Uses smoking, beer, and comfort food as coping mechanisms rather than constructive stress management.
Occasional panic-like episodes in tight social situations, masked by aggression.
Stresses about finances intermittently, especially when work dries up due to weather.
health.medical_history_summary: No hospitalizations in the past five years; treated minor fractures and lacerations on the job. Diagnosed with stage 1 hypertension a few years ago. Treated for a broken wrist in his early 30s after a ladder fall. Immunizations inconsistent, dental care sporadic.

relationships.name: Erin McCoy
relationships.description: Mid-30s, works part-time at a pharmacy. They have a tense partnership: she manages household finances quietly while he resents being told what to do. They bicker regularly; she balances managing the home and keeping kids steady. Erin is the emotional laborer; Shane often takes her for granted but would react viscerally if she left.

relationships.name: Tanner McCoy
relationships.description: Teenager learning trade skills from Shane. Shane wants Tanner to learn to rely on his hands and hates when Tanner is distracted by phones or 'city' ideas. Their relationship is practical: mentoring mixed with sarcasm and frequent criticism. He is proud of Tanner when the boy does something well but expresses it poorly.

relationships.name: Maggie Lee (mother)
relationships.description: Early 60s, small-town matriarch. Still a primary emotional anchor; she calls Shane out on his rudeness and he softens temporarily around her. They exchange sharp barbs but deep familial loyalty remains.

relationships.name: Billy 'Two-Bits' Hensley
relationships.description: A fellow tradesman who shares beers, hunting reports, and gossip. He tolerates Shane's nastiness because Shane is dependable with tools and cash.

relationships.name: Local contractor clients and neighbors
relationships.description: A mix of people who rely on his hands but complain about his attitude. He has a reputation: highly competent but a pain to work with. He gets repeat business because he gets jobs done cheap and quick.

relationships.name: Estranged older brother (Ethan)
relationships.description: Moved away years ago and pursued a steady white-collar career. They rarely speak and exchange passive-aggressive jabs when contact occurs. Shane views Ethan as a 'sellout' and Ethan views Shane as trapped.

other_facts: Grew up in a three-bedroom trailer; family always made do with what they had.
First learned carpentry fixing up an old farmhouse with his uncle at age 13.
Dropped out of community college night classes after one semester when a job offered immediate pay.
Once built a small backyard shed for a neighbor for free after an argument; denied it was charity later.
Has an old, dented 2001 Ford F-250 he calls 'the mule' that he refuses to sell though it's smoky and missing trim.
Keeps a roll of duct tape, a pry bar, and an old pocket knife in his back pocket at all times.
A memorable fight at age 19 after a bar argument left him with a scar over his left eyebrow.
Lost a close friend in a worksite accident a decade ago — still refuses to talk about it in detail but vows to 'do better' in a gruff way.
Once shamed a city inspector publicly for trying to fine a neighbor — gained local notoriety for standing up to 'the man.'
Has a small stash of cash hidden in a tin can under the garage floorboards for emergencies.
Kept a scrapbook of hunting trophies and faded newspaper clippings about local high school sports he used to follow.
Tells a story about gutting his first deer to anyone who will listen; glorifies the competence of the act.
Took a short, prideful course in welding at a local fair years back and still brags about a makeshift gate he welded.
Refers to his childhood dog, 'Blue', as the best companion he ever had and keeps a faded photo of Blue in his wallet.
Once tried to flip a small rental property and failed due to an unexpected roof collapse; still blames the previous owner's 'trashwork.'
Regularly checks a county forum for odd jobs and occasionally undercuts other tradesmen's quotes to get work.
Has a grudging respect for a rival contractor who does neat finishing work — calls him an 'overly tidy pain' but secretly admires the craft.
Keeps a worn leather-bound notebook where he scribbles measurements, debts owed to him, and crude sketches of builds.
His preferred lighter is a battered Zippo with his initials scratched on the side.
Refuses to wear hearing protection consistently, brags about 'being able to hear fine' though ringing in ears suggests otherwise.
Has an old high school football jersey hidden in a box — the only item he cherishes privately and seldom admits to keeping.
Once organized a neighborhood informal tool swap day, which ended with slights and unresolved debts; he still mutters about it.
Traded work on a roof for an old boat once; the boat sits half-fixed and is a source of both pride and shame.
Was briefly arrested in his early 20s after a brawl; the charges were dropped but the story is told as proof of toughness.
Keeps an emergency kit in the truck: flashlight, spare battery, rope, a can of beans, and a small first-aid kit.
Once lost a close job opportunity by insulting a client's taste; still defends his criticism as 'honesty.'
Gave his son Tanner an old hammer when the boy turned 13, telling him 'learn to make things or you'll learn to beg.'
Hates therapy but once went to a court-mandated anger-management class and complains about it endlessly.
Believes he's 'lucky' his hands are still useful; worries about the day his body won't cooperate.
Has an uneasy relationship with credit; uses it only when forced and still keeps receipts from decades ago.
Took a high-school welding teacher's advice to 'never let anyone tell you you can’t do a thing with your hands' and still repeats it to younger men.
Is suspicious of online strangers but participates in conspiracy-leaning message boards for entertainment and validation.
Was the kid in school who managed to skate by academically, but excelled at shop class; that shaped his respect for practical skills.
Once gave a stray cat food and a place under the porch until it disappeared; he insists he 'doesn't do pets,' but fosters animals privately sometimes.
Has a handshake that lingers slightly too long — part intimidation, part habit.
Refuses to wear business attire for anything; will show up in work clothes to meet a bank manager if necessary.
Keeps a list of people who owe him favors in his head and brings them up in conversations years later when convenient.
Sings along badly and loudly to classic country songs in the truck, using them to drown out worries.
Had a brief flirtation with learning to run a small YouTube channel for hunting tips but stopped after negative comments enraged him.
Says his proudest moment was fixing his father's roof after a storm when no one else would show up.
Practices a nightly ritual of checking doors and outdoor lights three times before bed; claims it's practical, but it’s also an anxiety quirk.
Keeps a small jar of marbles in the kitchen as a game he plays with his son to teach counting and bargaining.
Has a secret soft spot for old Westerns that he watches with low volume while doing paperwork; the stoic heroes resonate with him.
Used to weld initials into the back of a leather jacket for a now-deceased buddy; the act is one of the rare times he shows tenderness.
Maintains a running tally of insults and perceived slights in his head — uses them as justification for future coldness.
Still remembers every contractor who stiffed him on payment in the last decade and politely refuses to do business with them.
